VISUALFORCE B2B COMMERCE
Considerations for Storefront User Experience Customizations

Fulfill your storefront's unique requirements and ensure that you still deliver a trusted experience that's easy to maintain and upgrade. Review the following considerations for customizing the default storefront functionality, and minimize the extent that you develop, test, and support custom code.

REQUIRED EDITIONS

Salesforce Compatibility

Salesforce Classic (not available in all orgs) and Lightning Experience for Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions.




B2B Commerce Compatibility

B2B Commerce for Visualforce Winter ’21 (version 4.13)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’20 (version 4.12)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’19 (version 4.11)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’19 (version 4.10)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’18 (version 4.9)

We recommend that you adhere to the following priorities when you implement your solution's unique requirements:

Configure
Extend
Replace
Configure

As much as possible, set appropriate values for the default storefront settings and configuration settings. These settings represent default options in the managed package that Salesforce develop, tests, and supports. Subsequent patch or major releases of the managed package can fix performance or security issues that affect these settings. Upgrading to a new version of the managed package preserves the options you already specified. Settings are available several relatively simple customizations that you're probably going to complete anyway, such as:

Enabling or disabling a widget or behavior.
Showing or hiding certain data.
Specifying criteria or default state for certain features, such as default sort criteria for products on the Product List page or the workflow for the Checkout page.
Replacing the default storefront theme with a custom theme that reflects your brand's visual identity.
Changing a page's default layout to use a different arrangement of columns.

For more information about what functionality you can specify with the default storefront settings and configuration settings, review the following topics:

Storefront General Settings
List of Configuration Modules and Settings
Configure the Default Storefront Pages
Add Widgets to Storefront Pages with Visualforce Components
Modify the Column Layout of a Storefront Page
Style Your Storefront with a Theme
Extend

If the default storefront settings or configuration settings don't provide a solution for your unique requirements, you can extend some parts of a storefront page. B2B Commerce provides some default extension points in a page's HTML structure where you can:

Gross layout override
Modify the arrangement of the major components that a buyer can see on a page, including the header, navigational menu, Splash widget, body content, and footer. For example, use a gross layout override when you want to swap the locations of the storefront header and the navigational menu. For more information, see Create a Gross Layout Override.
Subscriber template
Specify a custom template for the page's body content, instead of using a default column layout template. Use a subscriber template when you want to modify the arrangement of widgets in a way that the default configuration settings don't allow. For example, maybe you want to move the Search Box widget to the main content column instead of the left or right column. For more information, see Create a Subscriber Template.
Page include
Insert, extend, or override content in a specific location in a default page or widget. This extension is known as a page include. Use a page include when you want to customize the data or functionality for default components. For example, use a page include when you want to modify the data shown in the Mini Cart widget or add a button on the Shopping Cart page. For more information, see Create a Page Include.

For more information about all the available extension points, see Extension Points in a Storefront Page.

Replace

Finally, if you can't achieve your solution's requirements using any configuration or extension options, you can create an entire custom page, known as a subscriber page. Create a subscriber page when you want to build a page for content that's not available in the managed package. For example, maybe you want a page for a loyalty program, show reviews and testimonials, or showcase your organization's values and history.

NOTE We recommend that you don't use a subscriber page to replace functionality of a default page type, such as the Product List page or Shopping Cart page. To ensure that your solution remains secure and easy to maintain, always continue using the managed package versions of those default page types. To customize those page types, use the available configuration or extension options.
Other Customization Considerations

When you create Visualforce pages for subscriber templates, page includes, or subscriber pages, keep the following guidelines in mind when you author code:

We recommend that new solutions always use Bootstrap 3-enabled templates for pages and components.
For HTML elements, apply Bootstrap 3 CSS styles. For easier maintenance and better reusability, avoid hard-coding specific styles.
Use page labels for buyer-facing text and calls to action. For more information, see Customize Storefront Headings and Text with Page Labels.
If you're customizing components, review Code That Renders Storefront Components for more information about how backbone.js, handlebars.js, and uiproperties.js help render content on the page.
When you override default handlebars.js templates, consider using a separate Visualforce component for each override. Then, reference each component from your page include. We recommend this method of organizing your custom code for easier readability, maintainability, and reuse. For example, the default Checkout page references separate components for the shipping address, payment information, order summary, and so on.
If you're referencing image files, review Source Options for Storefront Media.
Avoid calling any of the default Apex remote actions that the managed package uses, and instead call methods of the B2B Commerce for Visualforce global API. Remote actions are public and can change behavior between releases.
To invoke a custom Apex remote action, use the CCRZ.RemoteInvocation object functions defined in CC_Backbone.js. Avoid using Visualforce.remoting.Manager.invokeAction.
Use the JSINHTMLENCODE function for encoding values. For more information, see https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.pages.meta/pages/pages_variables_functions.htm.
